it.matjaz.numerus

Class RomanNumeral

  • java.lang.Object
    • it.matjaz.numerus.RomanNumeral
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable, CharSequence, Cloneable

    public class RomanNumeral
extends Object
implements Serializable, Cloneable, CharSequence
    A container for syntactically correct roman numerals saved as strings.

    This class saves a string passed though the constructor or the setter if and only if is a roman number with a correct syntax, which happens if the string matches the CORRECT_ROMAN_SYNTAX_REGEX.

    Any string with other characters, different order, too many characters or anyhow incorrect syntax gets refused with IllegalNumeralSyntaxException, which may contain some indication of the syntax error in the Exception message.

    The structure of a syntactically roman numeral is composed of the following characters in this order:

        0-3 M
        0-1 CM or 0-1 CD or ( 0-1 D and 0-3 C )
        0-1 XC or 0-1 XL or ( 0-1 L and 0-3 X )
        0-1 IX or 0-1 IV or ( 0-1 V and 0-3 I )
        only NULLA instead of any other symbol.

    For the integer values of the symbols, see RomanCharMapFactory.

    Author:
    Matja≈æ dev@matjaz.it matjaz.it
    See Also:

    • Field Detail

      • CORRECT_ROMAN_SYNTAX_REGEX

        public static final String CORRECT_ROMAN_SYNTAX_REGEX
        Big regex matching all syntactically correct roman numerals.

        Contains all possible cases of roman numerals. If a string does not match this regex, then is not a roman numeral. The structure of a syntactically roman numeral is composed of the following numeral in this order:

            0-3 M
            0-1 CM or 0-1 CD or ( 0-1 D and 0-3 C )
            0-1 XC or 0-1 XL or ( 0-1 L and 0-3 X )
            0-1 IX or 0-1 IV or ( 0-1 V and 0-3 I )
            only NULLA instead of any other symbol.

        Source of the idea of this regex with a great explanation.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • NON_ROMAN_CHARS_REGEX

        public static final String NON_ROMAN_CHARS_REGEX
        Regex matching any non roman characters.

        If a string contains any character matching with this regex, then is not a roman numeral, because contains illegal characters.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • NULLA

        public static final String NULLA
        String indicating the roman numeral with value zero, 0.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

    • Constructor Detail

      • RomanNumeral

        public RomanNumeral()
        Constructs a RomanNumeral initialized to NULLA.

        Contains "NULLA" numerals indicating zero value.

      • RomanNumeral

        public RomanNumeral(String symbols)
             throws IllegalNumeralSyntaxException
        Constructs a RomanNumeral initialized with the given value.

        The passed string gets checked for syntax correctness. If the syntax is illegal, then a IllegalNumeralSyntaxException is thrown.

        Whitespace charactes in the passed String are removed and the characters are upcased.

        Parameters:
        symbols - the initial roman numeral to be stored.
        Throws:
        IllegalNumeralSyntaxException - when string has illegal roman syntax.

    • Method Detail

      • getNumeral

        public String getNumeral()
        Getter of the roman numerals String.
        Returns:
        a String containing the roman numeral.

      • isNulla

        public boolean isNulla()
        Checks if this RomanNumeral contains a numeral other than NULLA.

        Returns true if this RomanNumeal has a roman numeral stored in it that indicates a non-zero value, that is a non-NULLA numeral. Else false if contains a NULLA string.

        Immediatly after calling the default constructor (the one without parameters), this method will return true.

        Returns:
        true has a NULLA numeral stored in it, else false.

      • setNumeral

        public void setNumeral(String numeral)
                throws IllegalNumeralSyntaxException
        Setter of the roman numerals String.

        The passed string gets checked for syntax correctness. If the syntax is illegal, then a IllegalNumeralSyntaxException is thrown.

        Whitespace charactes in the passed String are removed and the characters are upcased.

        Parameters:
        numeral - the new roman numeral to be stored.
        Throws:
        IllegalNumeralSyntaxException - when the passed string has illegal roman syntax.

      • isCorrectRomanSyntax

        public static boolean isCorrectRomanSyntax(String numeralsToCheck)
        Performs a check of the syntax of the given roman numeral without storing it in a RomanNumeral.

        Returns true if the passed String matches the syntax of roman numerals; else false. Useful to just quickly check if a String is a roman numeral when an instance of it is not needed. If the result is true, then the passed String can be successfully stored in a RomanNumeral by constructor or setter.

        Parameters:
        numeralsToCheck - the String to check the roman syntax on.
        Returns:
        true if the passed String is a roman numeral; else false.

      • hashCode

        public int hashCode()
        Returns the hash of this RomanNumeral.

        The hashcode is created using only the roman numeral String in this RomanNumeral. Uses Objects.hashCode(java.lang.Object) and overrides Object.hashCode().

        Overrides:

        Returns:

        public boolean equals(Object otherRomanNumeral)
        Verifies if the passed Object is equal to this.

      • toString

        public String toString()
        Returns a String representation of this RomanNumeral, which is the roman numeral String stored in it.

        This method is a delegate method and just calls getNumeral() so the returned string is exactly the same for both. This method is here for compatibility reasons.

        Specified by:
        toString in interface CharSequence
        Overrides:
        toString in class Object
        Returns:
        a String containing the roman numeral.
        See Also:
        getNumeral(), Object.toString()

      • clone

        public RomanNumeral clone()
                   throws CloneNotSupportedException
        Returns a clone of this object with the same numeral.

        The original and the RomanNumeral store an equal roman numeral and applying an equals() method to them, will result true.

        Since the only field of RomanNumeral is a String, the CloneNotSupportedException should never raise.

        Delegates Object.clone().

        Overrides:
        clone in class Object
        Returns:
        a RomanNumeral with the same numeral.
        Throws:
        CloneNotSupportedException - when super object is not cloneable.
        See Also:
        Object.clone()

      • subSequence

        public CharSequence subSequence(int startIncluded,
                                int endNotIncluded)
        Returns a CharSequence containing a part of this RomanNumeral.

        The returned CharSequence contains the characters of the roman numeral from the start index (included) to the end index (exluded).

        Delegates String.subSequence(int, int).

        Specified by:
        subSequence in interface CharSequence
        Parameters:
        startIncluded - index of the first character to be included.
        endNotIncluded - index of the first character after the end of the wanted part.
        Returns:
        a part of the roman numeral as CharSequence.
        See Also:
        String.subSequence(int, int)
